There are now just over two weeks left until the closing of this question, and it seems more unlikely than ever at this point that the Games will be canceled. While the Olympics have been canceled or postponed in the past, never before has such an announcement come so close to the commencement of the event. In fact, this is an extraordinarily rare occurrence for any mass international sporting event, and those movements/cancellations have almost always come as a response to a completely unprecedented event - typically natural disasters or similarly catastrophic events. In this case, base-rate comparisons are likely not as important as the specifics of the situation itself, and a variety of developments across the spectrum of interested parties have clarified that it would take a situation similarly shocking to last year's Covid cancellation in order to force another postponement of the Olympics. The IOC generates $4bn in advertising revenue from the Olympics each cycle, which given the Summer Games' popularity relative to the Winter Games implies Summer ad revenue of ~ $2.5bn. Given pressure from these sponsors, particularly television rightsholders like NBC, and the potential perception hit the IOC might take from a full-on cancellation given their already unsavory reputation, the IOC's incentives are strongly aligned in favor of holding the Games. Additionally, the IOC/Japan contract gives the IOC the ultimate authority as to whether or not the Games will go ahead, so even if Japan's government is against the Olympics proceeding, they'd need to take extreme action in order to prevent them from occurring at the given start date. The other primary stakeholder in this situation is the country of Japan, which may face the strongest incentive to postpone or cancel the Olympics given the public pressure to do so - upwards of 80%, given the country's relatively low vaccination rate (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/olympics/ahead-tokyo-olympics-japan-vaccination-rate-far-mark-n1272523) and the push by medical professionals and news media to more strongly consider that possibility (https://www.espn.com/radio/play/_/id/31519855). However, while the Japanese government would be the body most responsive to public opinion, there are several reasons why them doing so and not proceeding with the Games is unlikely: 1. Sunk-cost fallacy -- Japan has already spent ~ $30bn on preparations for the Games over the past decade. Not holding the Olympics would "waste" all this work, and although it's a sunk cost and shouldn't be taken into account, there's a strong emotional attachment to the Games on the part of Japan's government, which leads to...
2. The Games' purpose -- Japan won the bid to host the Olympics under the narrative that it would showcase the country's rebound from the earthquake/nuclear disaster of 2011, a bid led by the Japanese government. This narrative has now pivoted to a worldwide Covid recovery-oriented one as the first Olympics since the onset of the pandemic, and as a country that has handled the pandemic relatively well vs. other nations, Japan's leaders are invested in showing the world the strength of both their disaster and Covid recoveries.
3. Response to public opinion -- the current Japanese government, which supports holding the Games, is up for reelection this fall. This would normally give rise to concern about the possible negative impact of ignoring public opinion with an election in the near future, but the ruling Liberal Democratic Party has won sound victories of > 12% in every election since 2012. This implies that even a move towards opposition parties would still leave the LDP in a strong political position, lessening their concern about possibly losing power.
4. Preparation efforts -- this does not mean that Japan is taking no steps to respond to the concerns of their population. Stadium capacity is limited to local residents at 50% with no cheering allowed, and the typically active Olympic Village is siloed to prevent excess interaction amongst athletes and with the larger Tokyo population. There are also very strict protocols regarding the teams themselves - for example, in gymnastics, if one team member tests positive for Covid-19, every team member is no longer able to compete. While some may view such measures as excessive, it's an indicator that there has been a measurable response to the concerns raised by Japanese citizens. In summation, with only two weeks until the close-out period of this question, my estimates have been revised significantly downwards to where I believe it's extremely unlikely it's announced the Games will not proceed in July 2021.

We have a precedent in that these Tokyo Games have been postponed already given Covid-19 so let's see what the situation was with the pandemic back in March 2020 when they make the decision to delay the Games. I think there is a larger probability for it happening in 2 months, but we only have 4 weeks to play with for this question.  Therefore my inside probability is 0.25. Probability = Outside + Inside

This means we have an updated probability of ~16% of cancellation.
3. Moving to specific concerns in 2021, Japan has been faced with numerous challenges including 10000 volunteers who have recently pulled out of the games and intensely negative domestic sentiment towards the games.
